content.definition: A congenital vascular malformation with direct arteriovenous connections (nidus) without intervening capillary bed. High-flow lesions that enlarge over time and do not spontaneously regress. Distinguished from hemangiomas (tumors that regress) and other vascular malformations by hemodynamic characteristics.

presentation: Limb length discrepancy (if involving growth plate)

schobinger_staging.Stage_II: Expansion - pulsation, thrill, bruit, tortuous veins

diagnosis: Doppler ultrasound: low-resistance arterial flow, arterialized veins
MRI/MRA: defines extent, relationship to structures
Angiography: identifies feeding arteries, nidus, draining veins

management.embolization: Ethanol, Onyx, coils - reduce flow, palliative or pre-surgical

principles: Partial treatment may worsen (recruitment of collaterals)
Goal is complete excision or nidus destruction

clinical_pearls: AVMs present at birth, hemangiomas appear after birth
AVMs grow with patient, hemangiomas involute by age 10
Proximal ligation is ineffective and harmful (recruits collaterals)
Ethanol most effective sclerosant but highest complication rate
High-output failure rare but indicates very large shunt volume

learning_objectives: Understand treatment principles for high-flow malformations
